arch:property.oc:show_val: Ashy layer of fill in north corner of trench. Originally a part of L156; it became apparent that this was very different material and a softer consistency, thus we made it its own locus. Very few small finds, mostly lithics. It is ashy and different enough throughout the locus for it to legitimately be its own locus.The dividing line between this locus and L156, L163, L164, and L166 is not clearmeaining that material classified as belonging to one locus could actually belong to another. This is something to keep in mind when looking at this locus. These loci are producing similar enough finds that it does not make much of a difference. The locus was ashy near the top, and as we uncovered more it lost most of its ashyness, but did stay softer and very different than the abutting series of surfaces. The finds that came out of it lead us to believe it was definitely not a surface. Any trace of it disappeared into L170.
Ashier context than the surrounding loci, especially near its top; softer than the surrounding soil from other loci.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area E / Trench 2 / Locus 159 (Locus)
